subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: OK, we re not talking about TeX any more, right? So you use the backquote when simply typing? That seems unusal to me--it seems like most people simply use the
messageBody:
OK, we're not talking about TeX any more, right?

So you use the backquote when simply typing? That seems unusal to
me--it seems like most people simply use the apostrophe twice in both
positions. Because of this, I have the impression that it's among the
least used keys, and it's one of the reasons I like using it for the
name dot.

If that's not the case, I prefer the tilda to the slash for the name dot.

Ted


On Dec 4, 2007 1:57 PM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
>
> Couldn't that be handled with a TeX escape sequence or something? In
> other contexts, I think very few people need the backquote, which is
> one of the reasons I suggested it. Another possibility I like is the
> tilda, '~', but I think people would want to type a tilda once in a
> while. I'm open to other possibilites that (1) are 7-bit ASCII, (2)
> are easy to type, and (3) are visually reminiscent of the name dot.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> The backquote (`) is used as a shorthand for smart (curly) quotes:
>
> ``My heart leaps up when I behold a rainbow in the sky.''
>
> ``mY hArt lipz yp W Y bihOld y renbo In D skY.''
>
> If you have to escape the backquote, you lose the purpose of using it. How
> often do we really use the backslash when writing QS?
>
> Paul
>
>
>
>
